page.title: 03BURY HILL LAKE
page.content: To most travellers along the A25 west of Dorking, the entrance to the Bury Hill Lake access road is merely a place to park a caravan, lorry or car for a few minutes rest. To the locals it is a well-trodden road to their favourite leisure activity. Bury Hill Lake is situated to the south of the Nower and is popular with local fishermen who pay a daily fee to fish its waters. Access is difficult except for fishermen and the area is controlled by a warden. The lake is well stocked with{Roach, Bream, Carp, {Tench and Rudd.} A study of the marginal plants of the lake reveals that{Yellow Flag and {Common Reed}are most often found.{ {Sweet Flag,}a rare plant in England, may also be found here. Species of wildfowl include{Moorhens {Canada Geese, Mallards, Coot, Herons.
